statement:
The purpose of this entry is to collect properties of and commutator
subgroups. Feel free to add more theorems!

Let $G$ be a group.

\[thm:inversecommutator\] Let $x,y\in G$, then $[x,y]^{-1}=[y,x]$.

Direct computation yields
$$[x,y]^{-1}=(x^{-1}y^{-1}xy)^{-1}=y^{-1}x^{-1}yx=[y,x].$$

Let $X,Y$ be subsets of $G$, then $[X,Y]=[Y,X]$.

By Theorem \[thm:inversecommutator\], the elements from $[X,Y]$ or
$[Y,X]$ are products of commutators of the form $[x,y]$ or $[y,x]$ with
$x\in X$ and $y\in Y$.

Let $x,y,z\in G$, then
$$y^{-1}[x,y^{-1},z]yz^{-1}[y,z^{-1},x]zx^{-1}[z,x^{-1},y]x=1.$$

This is mainly a brute-force calculation. We can easily calculate the
first factor $y^{-1}[x,y^{-1},z]y$ explicitly using
theorem \[thm:inversecommutator\]: $$\begin{aligned}
&y^{-1}[x,y^{-1},z]y\\
=&y^{-1}[y^{-1},x]z^{-1}[x,y^{-1}]zy\\
=&y^{-1}yx^{-1}y^{-1}xz^{-1}x^{-1}yxy^{-1}zy\\
=&x^{-1}y^{-1}xz^{-1}x^{-1}yxy^{-1}zy.\end{aligned}$$ Let
$h_1:=x^{-1}y^{-1}xz^{-1}x^{-1}$, the “first half” of
$y^{-1}[x,y^{-1},z]y$. Let $h_2$ be the element obtained from $h_1$ by
the cyclic shift $S\colon x\mapsto y\mapsto z\mapsto x$, and $h_3$ be
the element obtained from $h_2$ by $S$. We have
$$h_2^{-1}=(y^{-1}z^{-1}yx^{-1}y^{-1})^{-1}=yxy^{-1}zy$$ which gives us
$$y^{-1}[x,y^{-1},z]y=h_1h_2^{-1},$$ and, by applying $S$ twice
$$\begin{aligned}
z^{-1}[y,z^{-1},x]z&=h_2h_3^{-1},\\
x^{-1}[z,x^{-1},y]x&=h_3h_1^{-1}.\end{aligned}$$ In total, we have
$$y^{-1}[x,y^{-1},z]yz^{-1}[y,z^{-1},x]zx^{-1}[z,x^{-1},y]x=h_1h_2^{-1}h_2h_3^{-1}h_3h_1^{-1}=1.$$

Let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$. Furthermore, let $X$, $Y$ and $Z$
be subgroups of $G$, such that $[X,Y,Z]$ and $[Y,Z,X]$ are contained in
$N$. Then $[Z,X,Y]$ is contained in $N$ as well.

The group $[Z,X,Y]$ is generated by all elements of the form
$[z,x^{-1},y]$ with $x\in X$, $y\in Y$ and $z\in Z$. Since $N$ is
normal, $y^{-1}[x,y^{-1},z]y$ and $x^{-1}[z,x^{-1},y]x$ are elements of
$N$. The Hall–Witt identity then implies that $x^{-1}[z,x^{-1},y]x$ is
an element of $N$ as well. Again, since $N$ is normal,
$[z,x^{-1},y]\in N$ which concludes the proof.

For any $x, y, z \in G$ we have $$\begin{aligned}
 [xy, z] & = & [x,z]^y [y,z] \\
 {[}x,yz] & = & [x,z][x,y]^z \\
 {[}x,y]^z & = & [x^z, y^z] \\
 {[}x^z, y] & = & [x, y^{z^{-1}}] \end{aligned}$$ where $a^b$ denotes
$b^{-1} a b$

By expanding: $$\begin{aligned}
 [xy,z] & = & y^{-1}x^{-1} z^{-1} xyz \\
& = & y^{-1} x^{-1} z^{-1} \cdot xz \cdot z^{-1} x^{-1} \cdot xyz \\
&=& y^{-1} [x,z] \cdot y \cdot y^{-1} \cdot z^{-1} x^{-1} \cdot xyz \\
&=& [x,z]^y \cdot y^{-1} z^{-1} y z \\
&=& [x,z]^y [y,z]\end{aligned}$$ The other identities are proved
similarly.
names: properties of group commutators and commutator subgroups
